questions.text: TCA is an amphibolic pathway with many of its intermediates are part of other catabolic and anabolic reactions. All of the following are intermediates of the TCA cycle, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malonate Malonate is not an intermediate of the TCA cycle It is an inhibitor of: TCA cycle (a competitive inhibitor of enzyme succinate dehydrogenase) ETC (component inhibited is Complex II) Beta Oxidation of Fatty Acids (Enz inhibited is Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-1 CPT-1) Note: Do not confuse malonate with malate (intermediate in the TCA cycle)

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options B, C, and D alpha-ketoglutarate, Succinate, and Fumarate TCA cycle intermediates are (see fig.) Citrate, Isocitrate α-ketoglutarate succinyl-CoA Succinate Fumarate Malate oxaloacetate Acetyl-CoA is completely oxidized Oxaloacetate is regenerated

questions.text: Anaplerotic (gap-filling) reactions are the reactions that replenish the depleted TCA cycle intermediates that were used up in the biosynthesis reactions. Which of the following is the major anaplerotic enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyruvate carboxylase Oxaloacetate (OAA) is regarded as a carrier and 1st substrate of the TCA cycle. Thus, the production of oxaloacetate is the major anaplerotic reaction. Intermediate Depleted (used) by Replenished by Oxaloacetate Amino Acid synthesis, gluconeogenesis ● Pyruvate carboxylase (Major anaplerotic enzyme) from pyruvate ● Transaminase from aspartate ● PEP carboxykinase and PEP carboxylase from PEP Succinyl-CoA Heme Synthesis ● Propionyl-CoA carboxylase and Methyl malonyl-CoA mutase reactions from propionyl-CoA α-ketoglutarate TCA ● Glutamate dehydrogenase from glutamate ● Alanine transaminase from alanine Malate Gluconeogenesis ● Malic enzyme from pyruvate

Random:

Option B: Acetyl CoA Carboxylase Acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of cytosolic de novo fatty acid synthesis. It catalyzes the first step of fatty acid synthesis by carboxylation of acetyl CoA molecule to form malonyl CoA. It is not an anaplerotic reaction Option C: Pyruvate dehydrogenase PDH forms acetyl CoA from pyruvate by oxidative decarboxylation. Acetyl CoA is not an intermediate of TCA so not an anaplerotic reaction It can be formed from a large number of reactions in the cell. Option D: Succinate dehydrogenase It forms fumarate from succinate both of which are intermediate of TCA. In other words, it consumes one TCA intermediate to form another TCA intermediate So, not an anaplerotic reaction

questions.text: Reduced coenzymes NADH and FADH2 are formed in reactions catalyzed by dehydrogenases in the oxidative metabolism of carbohydrates. Which of the following is the FAD-linked dehydrogenase of the TCA cycle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Succinate dehydrogenase Succinate dehydrogenase is the only FAD-linked dehydrogenase in the TCA cycle. The reaction catalyzed by this enzyme is as:

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options A and B: Malate dehydrogenase and isocitrate dehydrogenase Both are NAD-linked dehydrogenases of the TCA cycle. MDH is a simple dehydrogenase whereas IDH also performs decarboxylation along with dehydrogenation. Their reactions are shown as: Option D: Glyceraldehyde 3-P dehydrogenase Glyceraldehyde 3-P dehydrogenase is a dehydrogenase of Glycolysis. Its also a NAD-linked dehydrogenase but also transfer Pi to its substrate glyceraldehyde 3-P

questions.text: TCA reactions are happening in the mitochondrial matrix for effective utilization, of reduced coenzymes generated in TCA, by ETC. All of the following TCA cycle dehydrogenases are located in the mitochondrial matrix, EXCEPT
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Succinate dehydrogenase Aka succinate-coenzyme Q reductase or respiratory complex II is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It is the only enzyme that simultaneously takes part in TCA, ETC The FAD cofactor is covalently attached to this enzyme. The electrons transferred from the succinate are directly feed in to ETC through the reduced coenzyme FADH 2 .

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and D: Malate dehydrogenase, Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and isocitrate dehydrogenase All of these dehydrogenases are present in the mitochondrial matrix. For reaction catalyzed by these enzymes, see explanation of the previous questions

questions.text: In the TCA cycle, two molecules of CO2 are produced along with the generation of reducing equivalents NADH and FADH2. Simultaneous oxidation and decarboxylation happen in the reaction catalyzed by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase Simultaneous removal of electrons and CO 2 from a substrate is called Oxidative There are total 4 dehydrogenases present in Kreb's cycle: Isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) α- Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex (α-KG DH) Succinate dehydrogenase Malate dehydrogenase Out of them, two catalyzes oxidative decarboxylation reactions: Isocitrate dehydrogenase α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: Malate dehydrogenase Catalyzes simple dehydrogenation of malate to regenerate TCA carrier oxaloacetate Use NAD as a coenzyme to transfer electrons from the substrate Option C: Succinate dehydrogenase Catalyzes simple dehydrogenation of succinate to form Fumarate Use prosthetic group FAD to transfer electrons from the substrate Is only membrane-bound enzyme of TCA and is also called as respiratory complex II Option D: Fumarase Catalyzes the formation of malate from fumarate It is a hydration reaction i.e. addition of water across a double bond to introduce an -OH group. So, this enzyme is not a dehydrogenase

questions.text: All of the following are tightly bound to component enzymes of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Coenzyme A CoA is a loosely bound cofactor of PDH component E2 Help enzyme in catalysis by accepting acetyl group from lipoamide Another loosely bound cofactor is NAD which is a cofactor of the E3 subunit of the enzyme

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Thiamine PyroPhosphate (TPP) Bound covalently to E 1 Decarboxylates pyruvate Option B: Lipoic acid Covalently linked to Lys on E 2 Accepts acetyl group from TPP Option C: Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) Bound by covalent linkage to E 2 Reduced by lipoamide PDH complex cofactors: Characteristic Cofactor Prosthetic groups TPP Lipoic Acid FAD Loosely bound groups NAD + CoA

questions.text: An individual display lactic acidemia as well as reduced activity of α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. The most likely single enzymatic mutation that leads to these changes would be in which one of the following proteins?

options.label: A
options.text: The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

options.label: B
options.text: The E1 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

options.label: C
options.text: The E2 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

questions.correct_answer: A. The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase, the dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase activity (with bound FAD), is identical to α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Mutation in this subunit would lead to an accumulation of pyruvate (because pyruvate dehydrogenase activity is reduced), and the accumulated pyruvate is converted to lactate.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options B and C: The E1 and E2 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase The E1 and E2 subunits of pyruvate dehydrogenase are unique to pyruvate dehydrogenase, and are not shared with any other enzymes, So defects in these subunits will lead to lactic acidemia but would not affect α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Option D: lactate dehydrogenase A defect in lactate dehydrogenase would result in an inability to produce lactate, So will not cause lactic acidemia.

questions.text: The TCA cycle is a common link between various metabolic pathways and plays a vital role in cell metabolism. The unavailability of which of the following will most adversely affect the TCA cycle:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oxaloacetate Regulation of the TCA cycle: TCA is a vital cycle with no hormonal control. However, some control is exerted by: Energy Status of the cell Availability of Oxaloacetate (not acetyl CoA) TCA is always active whether fed or fasting state However, it can get slower or faster depending on the availability of oxaloacetate. So, Oxaloacetate is regarded as: Carrier of TCA cycle 1st substrate of TCA catalytic role in TCA

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Acetyl CoA Acetyl CoA is never present in limited quantity in the cell So, it is never a factor in TCA control It is neither a carrier of TCA nor 1 st substrate or intermediate of the TCA cycle Options C and D: Insulin and Glucagon TCA is a vital cycle for the cells and is required under all the conditions So, it is kept free from hormonal control i.e. doesn't depend on insulin or glucagon.

questions.text: Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a vitamin B3 derivative acts as a cofactor for a number of catabolic enzymes. Which of the following TCA cycle enzyme/enzymes cannot perform their catalytic role in the absence of NAD? A. Citrate synthase B.Isocitrate dehydrogenase C. α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase D. Malate dehydrogenase E. Succinyl thiokinase Select the correct option form given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B, C, D B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase, C. α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase D. Malate dehydrogenase Requires NAD Requires FAD Isocitrate dehydrogenase Succinate dehydrogenase alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase Malate dehydrogenase

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Citrate Synthase Is the first enzyme of the TCA cycle Catalyzes a condensation reaction between acetyl CoA (2C) and oxaloacetate (4C) to form citrate (6C). Do not need any coenzyme for its function Option E: Succinyl thiokinase Aka Succinyl CoA synthetase Is an enzyme of substrate-level phosphorylation reaction of TCA Catalyzes the breaking of high energy bond of succinyl CoA to succinate and CoA and storing release energy in the form of ATP/GTP by transferring phosphoryl group to ADP/GDP.

questions.text: In the citric acid cycle, fumarate is converted to malate by the enzyme fumarase. This enzyme is an example of which of the following category of enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lyase Fumarase belongs to class Lyase – E nzyme Commission Number- 4 . It belongs to the category hydratase/hydrase enzymes which removes water to make a double bond or add water across a double bond, without breaking bond Other e.g. are Enolase, Aconitase, PEPCK

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: Hydrolase They break the bond by the addition of water EC Number of Hydrolase is 3. Examples of hydrolases: Digestive Enzymes: Breaks down macromolecules Phosphatase: remove the phosphate group from a substrate Option C: Ligase Catalyze the formation of C-C, C-N, C-O, and C-S bonds by condensation reaction using ATP EC Number of Ligase is 6. Examples of ligases are: Carboxylase: add CO 2 to a substrate Synthetases: Link two molecules using ATP

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Link reaction is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a link between TCA and ETC

options.label: B
options.text: This is the oxidative deamination of pyruvate

options.label: C
options.text: This is oxidative decarboxylation of Acetyl CoA

options.label: D
options.text: This reaction requires lipoic acid and 4 B-complex vitamins

questions.correct_answer: D. This reaction requires lipoic acid and 4 B-complex vitamins
questions.explanation:
Solution:

This reaction requires lipoic acid and 4 B-complex vitamins Link reactions are catalyzed by pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex. PDH complex has 5 coenzymes: Lipoic acid 4 B-complex vitamins: B 1 , B 2 , B 3 , B 5

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: This is a link between TCA and ETC Link reaction is a link between glycolysis and TCA (not TCA and ETC). Pyruvate formed in glycolysis is converted to acetyl CoA in mitochondria which enter TCA Options B and C: This is oxidative deamination of pyruvate It is oxidative decarboxylation (not oxidative deamination) of Pyruvate, not Acetyl CoA

questions.text: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase complex has all enzyme components EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyruvate Carboxylase It is an enzyme of gluconeogenesis. It catalyzes the carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate in mitochondria It is the most important anaplerotic reaction to replenish the TCA intermediate.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Aka E1 of PDH complex This enzyme removes CO 2 from pyruvate and transfers the hydroxyethyl group to the TPP coenzyme part of E1 This hydroxyethyl is then oxidized to the acetyl group and electrons are transferred to lipoic acid -S-S- of E2 to form reduced -SH Option B: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase aka E2 of PDH complex Trans-esterify the acetyl group between its lipoic acid moiety and CoA-SH to form acetyl CoA and also generate a second SH group. Option C: Dihydrolipoyl Dehydrogenase Aka E3 of PDH complex Transfers electrons from two - SH groups to FAD coenzyme to form FADH2 and regenerate oxidized S-S group. Transfer electrons from FADH 2 to NAD to form NADH

questions.text: Succinyl thiokinase of the TCA cycle belongs to the ligase category (EC no-6) of enzyme and catalyzes the only substrate-level phosphorylation step of TCA. Which of the high-energy molecules is produced by this enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ATP or GTP If the question specifically asks about thiokinase in the liver, kidney, and starvation then mark GTP, otherwise mark option "ATP or GTP"

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Options A and B: ATP and GTP Succinyl thiokinase produces ATP and GTP under different conditions and the different organs as shown in figure above. It produces ATP in non-glucogenic tissues It produces GTP in glucogenic tissues such as the liver, kidney, and under starvation. Option C: NADH Succinyl thiokinase is a kinase enzyme and kinase enzyme catalyzes a phosphorylation reaction to use or produce ATP or GTP. Production of NADH from NAD occurs by a reduction reaction by a dehydrogenase or reductase.

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions decreases the oxidation of acetyl CoA by the citric acid cycle?

options.label: B
options.text: A low NADH due to rapid oxidization to NAD+ through the respiratory chain

questions.explanation:
Solution:

A low NAD+/NADH ratio Covalent modification by the two regulatory enzymes that are part of the complex alternately activate and inactivate E1 (PDH). The cyclic AMP-independent PDH kinase phosphorylates and, thereby, inhibits E1, whereas PDH phosphatase dephosphorylates and activates E1. The kinase itself is allosterically activated by ATP, acetyl CoA, and NADH. Therefore, in the presence of these high-energy signals, the PDH complex is turned off. Pyruvate is a potent inhibitor of PDH kinase. Therefore, if pyruvate concentrations are elevated, E1 will be maximally active. Calcium is a strong activator of PDH phosphatase, stimulating E1 activity. This is particularly important in skeletal muscle, where the release of Ca2+ during contraction stimulates the PDH complex, thereby energy production. Although covalent regulation by the kinase and phosphatase is key, the complex is also subject to product (NADH, acetyl CoA) inhibition.

questions.text: Each round of TCA involves two oxidative decarboxylation reactions. 2 carbon atoms that are lost as CO2 are derived from:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oxaloacetate In the first round of the TCA cycle, the 2 Cs of acetyl CoA are transferred to oxaloacetate and are not released as CO 2 . In the 2nd round of the cycle, Cs from OAA and acetyl CoA are mixed and CO2 released may have C from Oxaloacetate or acetyl CoA. So, the best answer is oxaloacetate >> Acetyl CoA

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A: Acetyl CoA If oxaloacetate is not given in options, then mark acetyl CoA Option C: CO 2 CO 2 released in TCA is the bound CO 2 present in OAA or acetyl CoA Option D: Citrate Citrate is made by the combination of acetyl CoA and OAA in the first step of TCA It is then converted to isocitrate by isomerization which then undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to release CO 2 . So, Citrate or isocitrate cannot be the source of released CO 2

questions.text: As a general rule, rate-limiting steps or enzymes are generally considered the regulatory steps of any metabolic pathway. which of the following is the RLE of TCA?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above TCA is a vital pathway and is always active whether fed or fasting state So, it is not controlled by hormones However, the enzymes activity is affected by the availability of substrate 3 enzymes that are rate-limiting in the TCA cycle Citrate Synthase First enzyme and catalyzes the condensation of acetyl CoA and oxaloacetate Inhibitors: NADH, succinyl-CoA, citrate, ATP Activators: ADP Isocitrate Dehydrogenase catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-Ketoglutarate Inhibitors: ATP Activators: ADP, Ca 2+ Alpha-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of α-Ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA Inhibitors: NADH, succinyl-CoA Activators: Ca 2+

questions.text: A male child of age 2.6 years was taken to the hospital with manifestations of poor diet intake, nausea, abdominal pain, poor growth, occasional loss of consciousness, and rapid breathing. Clinical examination and tests revealed the presence of lactic acidosis, Hyperammonemia, prominent forehead, flared nostrils, and hypotonia. Plasma lactate, plasma pyruvate, plasma ammonia, and MRI were performed. The child was diagnosed with congenital deficiency of an enzyme mainly responsible for link reaction between metabolite of glycolysis and substrate of the TCA cycle. The diet which will be least helpful in the treatment of this patient will be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carbohydrate-rich diet Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency (also known as pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency or PDCD) is a rare neurodegenerative disorder associated with abnormal mitochondrial metabolism. The PDC is a multi-enzyme complex that plays a vital role as a key regulatory step in the central pathways of energy metabolism in the mitochondria. The disorder shows heterogeneous characteristics in both clinical presentation and biochemical abnormality. In PDH def, a carbohydrate-rich diet will result in the formation of a high concentration of pyruvate which will get converted into lactate and exaggerate the symptoms of lactic acidosis.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. A protein-rich diet will help as the most of end product of protein catabolism directly enters the TCA cycle bypassing the PDH reaction. Option: B. Ketogenic diet with high fats Ketogenic diets, with high fat and low carbohydrate intake, have been used to control or minimize lactic acidosis. Ketogenic baby formulas such as Nutricia KetoCal are available. With the ketogenic diet, ATP is synthesized by the catabolism of fatty acids rather than glucose, which produces the ketone bodies, 3-beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate, and acetone. Ketone bodies serve as an alternate source of energy for the body and the brain Option: D. A thiamine-supplemented diet Administration of thiamine is known to reduce serum lactate concentration in PDH deficiency patients and can improve his clinical symptoms as Thiamine is a cofactor of PDH which is deficient in this patient. But in case of a total lack of PDH activity, this might not cause any improvement.

questions.text: One of the major roles of the TCA cycle is to generate reduced cofactors for ATP production from oxidative phosphorylation. The net ATP yield when one molecule of pyruvate is completely oxidized to CO2 & H2O is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

12.5 The question says complete oxidation of pyruvate and not glucose, so we have to start with pyruvate without considering the glycolysis part. Net ATPs produced = 2.5 + 7.5 + 1.5 + 1.0 = 12.5 ATPs

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: B and C: 17.5 and 19.5 These are energetics when one molecule of glucose undergoes glycolysis and one pyruvate after glycolysis undergoes complete oxidation. Calculation: ATP from Glycolysis: Case I If NADH produced in glycolysis enters through the Glycerol 3-P shuttle Total ATP from glycolysis = 4 ATP (SLP) – 2 ATP (used in phase I) + 3 ATP (Oxidative Phosphorylation) = 5 ATP Case II If NADH produced in glycolysis enters through the malate shuttle Total ATP from glycolysis = 4 ATP (SLP) – 2 ATP (used in phase I) + 5 ATP (Oxidative Phosphorylation) = 7 ATP ATP from Pyruvate → TCA → ETC : One Pyruvate → CO 2 and H 2 O = 12.5 ATP (explained above) So Total ATP (Case I) = 12.5 + 5 = 17.5 ATP Total ATP (Case II) = 12.5 + 7 = 19.5 ATP Option D: 32 ATP When one glucose is completely oxidized to CO 2 and H 2 O and NADH use the Malate shuttle Total ATP produced = 7 ATP (Glucose to 2 Pyruvate) + 25 ATP (2 Pyruvate to CO 2 and H 2 O) = 32 ATP The energetics of complete oxidation of one pyruvate is 12.5 ATP while that of complete glucose is 32 ATP when the malate shuttle is used.

questions.text: Child of age 5 months was taken to the hospital with lethargy, vomiting and abnormally rapid breathing, and poor feeding. The infant exhibited signs of hypotonia, tachypnea, poor cognitive functions, mental retardation, and motor abnormalities. Examination and tests concluded the diagnosis of congenital lactic acidosis. Select the correct statement?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) deficiency is a genetic mitochondrial disease of carbohydrate metabolism that is due to a mutation in mtDNA. It is generally considered to be the most common cause of biochemically proven cases of congenital lactic acidosis. PDC deficiency can be inherited as an autosomal recessive or X-linked recessive trait. Most cases of congenital lactic acidosis are caused by one or more inherited mutations of genes within the DNA located within the nucleus (nDNA) or within the mitochondria (mtDNA) of cells. Genes carry the genetic instructions for cells. A mutation is a change in a gene located in nuclear or mitochondrial DNA that may cause disease Mutations affecting the genes for mitochondria (mtDNA) are inherited from the mother. mtDNA that is found in sperm cells is typically lost during fertilization. As a result, all human mtDNA comes from the mother. An affected mother will pass on the mutation to all her children, but only her daughters will pass on the mutation to their children.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase deficiency The development of hypertension is associated with mitochondrial redox balance disruptions. NADP+-dependent isocitrate dehydrogenase 2 (IDH2) plays an important role in the maintenance of mitochondrial redox balance\ Option: C. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase deficiency Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by partial or total inactivation of the mitochondrial enzyme alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Malate dehydrogenase deficiency Rare disease with only three patients described in the literature to date. MDH2D leads to an interruption of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle and malate-aspartate shuttle (MAS) and results in severe early-onset encephalopathy.
